search_results.title: Casual
search_results.lyrics:
Casual Lyrics[Verse 1]
My friends call me a loser
'Cause I'm still hanging around
I've heard so many rumors
That I'm just a girl that you bang on your couch
I thought you thought of me better
Someone you couldn't lose
You said, "We're not together"
So now when we kiss, I have anger issues

[Pre-Chorus]
You said, "Baby, no attachment"
But we're…
[Chorus]
Knee deep in the passenger seat and you're eating me out
Is it casual now?
Two weeks and your mom invites me to her house on Long Beach
Is it casual now?
I know what you tell your friends
It's casual, if it's casual now
But baby, get me off again
If it's casual, it's casual now

[Verse 2]
Dumb love, I love being stupid
Dream of us in a year
Maybe we'd have an apartment
And you'd show me off to your friends at the pier

[Pre-Chorus]
I know, "Baby, no attachment"
But we're…

[Chorus]
Knee deep in the passenger seat and you're eating me out
Is it casual now?
Two weeks and your mom invites me to her house on Long Beach
Is it casual now?
I know what you tell your friends
It's casual, if it's casual now
But baby, get me off again
If it's casual, oh, oh, oh
You might also like[Bridge]
It's hard being casual
When my favorite bra lives in your dresser
It's hard being casual
When I'm on the phone talking down your sister
And I try to be the chill girl that
Holds her tongue and gives you space
I try to be the chill girl but
Honestly, I'm not

[Chorus]
Knee deep in the passenger seat and you're eating me out
Two weeks and your mom invites me to her Long Beach house
I know what you tell your friends
Baby, get me off again
I fucked you in the bathroom when we went to dinner
Your parents at the table, you wonder why I'm bitter
Bragging to your friends I get off when you hit it
I hate to tell the truth but I'm sorry dude you didn't
I hate that I let this drag on so long, now I hate myself
I hate that I let this drag on so long, you can go to hell1Embed

description.plain:
Casual is an angsty slow-burn rock ballad bemoaning a situationship that is labeled as “casual” but clearly means more. In an interview with WECB.FM, Roan noted that the story is based off of a real life experience:

The whole song came from like, I heard from their friend that they were saying it was casual, when I didn’t think it was. I did not think it was, but apparently it was, so. And to me I was like, how could this be? How could this be casual?"

She elaborated further on the story of the song and music video for Coup de Main Magazine, saying:

The video is a representation of how I dream of a serious relationship with someone in my head, but in reality it may be far from that. Even if it may not feel like it, if there are no labels, it’s just casual."

song.embed_content: Read “Casual” by Chappell Roan on Genius
song.title: Casual

body.plain:
Casual is an angsty slow-burn rock ballad bemoaning a situationship that is labeled as “casual” but clearly means more. In an interview with WECB.FM, Roan noted that the story is based off of a real life experience:

The whole song came from like, I heard from their friend that they were saying it was casual, when I didn’t think it was. I did not think it was, but apparently it was, so. And to me I was like, how could this be? How could this be casual?"

She elaborated further on the story of the song and music video for Coup de Main Magazine, saying:

The video is a representation of how I dream of a serious relationship with someone in my head, but in reality it may be far from that. Even if it may not feel like it, if there are no labels, it’s just casual."

annotations:
I’ve heard so many rumors
 That I’m just a girl that you bang on your couch

In an interview with Pop Crave magazine, Roan admitted that her family hates this lyric:

My family doesn’t love this one, but [laughs and starts to sing]… I’ve heard so many rumors that I’m just a girl that you bang on your couch is probably my favorite. My mom can’t stand “Casual.” She’s like, “‘Eating me out’ is so gross! Why’d you have to say that?!” I was like, “Just be crazy! I don’t know. Say something bold!”

Dream of us in a year
 Maybe we’d have an apartment
 And you’d show me off to your friends at the pier

For Coup de Main Magazine:

I make up versions of the people I have feelings for. It’s very damaging, because they aren’t real, but the hope of becoming what I want them to be is what keeps me clinging to them. It’s very toxic. It’s unrealistic. Fantasizing is my downfall, but it brings out the best songs in me I guess."

I fucked you in the bathroom when we went to dinner
 Your parents at the table, you wonder why I’m bitter

More from the WECB.FM interview on this line:

Like I’m meeting your parents! And you wonder why I’m pissed off that you’re saying it’s casual! I used to be really bad about dissociating and going into this dream world of what I thought people were, and they just weren’t. I would have these crazy expectations of them and maybe that’s why they were like, ‘It’s casual, like, what are you talking about?’ But in my head, like I had made up this entire story, that didn’t exist. It’s a sad song, it’s revealing of my delusions."

It’s hard being casual
 When my favorite bra lives in your dresser
 It’s hard being casual
 When I’m on the phone talking down your sister
 And I try to be the chill girl that
 Holds her tongue and gives you space
 I try to be the chill girl but
 Honestly, I’m not

Some of Roan’s favorite lines in the song come from the bridge, according to her interview with WECB.FM:

It’s very interesting because like I always somehow remain close friends with my ex’s siblings. Like I would not be talking at all with my ex, but then I would be on the phone with their sister, and they’d be crying talking to me. That is interesting."

Knee deep in the passenger seat and you’re eating me out
 Is it casual now?
 Two weeks and your mom invites me to her house on Long Beach
 Is it casual now?

While Casual is inspired by real life experiences, Roan noted that some details were fictionalized:

Some of it was definitely fluffed, I guess. Like the first few lines of the chorus never happened–I never met their mom, you know, in Long Beach, or… never ate me out in a car, you know, but we made out in a car."

description.plain: This song is about a small southern girl dreaming about the drag club culture in Santa Monica, specifically being a dancer at the “Pink Pony Club”. She knows that her mom won’t be pleased, but she wants to follow her dreams anyways.

song.embed_content: Read “Pink Pony Club” by Chappell Roan on Genius

song.title: Pink Pony Club

annotatable.link_title: Pink Pony Club by Chappell Roan
annotatable.title: Pink Pony Club

body.plain: This song is about a small southern girl dreaming about the drag club culture in Santa Monica, specifically being a dancer at the “Pink Pony Club”. She knows that her mom won’t be pleased, but she wants to follow her dreams anyways.

annotations:
It’s where I belong down at the
 Pink Pony club

Moving to Los Angeles in 2018 allowed Roan to live freely as queer woman for the first time in her life:

I feel allowed to be who I want to be here. That changed everything."

When writing this song, she also planned to have drag performers open for her if she ever took it on tour, in homage to her time at the Abbey. In 2023, Roan performed alongside local drag queens in Nashville the same day that the Tennesse General Assembly passed a bill prohibiting drag shows in non age-restricted venues. Of the show, she said:

It was a very emotional show, it was heartbreaking,” she says passionately, tearing up. “To know that I was one of the last shows that would happen with all ages with drag performers [for now] is just… I am not scared, because the queer community is strong, we have each other’s backs, and we will overcome hate. We always do. I will continue doing drag. We will continue this, this is not stopping.”

I’m having wicked dreams
 Of leaving Tennessee
 Oh, Santa Monica
 I swear it’s calling me

Despite naming Tennessee in the pre-chorus, Roan actually grew up in Willard, Missouri. She talked a bit about her experience growing up there in a 2022 profile with Rolling Stone:

I felt so out of place in my hometown,” the now-24-year-old recalls. “I wish it was better. I wish I had better things to say. But mentally, I had a really tough time.”

And mama, every Saturday
 I can hear your southern drawl a thousand miles away, saying
Every Saturday that she performs, she can still “hear” her mother’s disapproval.

Don’t think I’ve left you all behind
 Still love you and Tennessee
 You’re always on my mind
Despite leaving Tennessee, she’s still in touch with where she once was. She hasn’t forgot about anybody there and especially not her mother.

I thank my wicked dreams
 A year from Tennessee
She’s grateful that she had these so-called “wicked” dreams because they lead her to happiness.
Every night’s another reason why I left it all
Thoroughly enjoying her time there, she has little to no regrets about leaving her home town. Every single night she spends doing what she does, she’s being captivated more and more into staying.
I’m up and jaws are on the floor

Everybody watching her in the audience at the bar really likes her. They are impressed and mesmerised by her. This gives the girl a confidence boost and allows her to see further that this is right for her.

I’m gonna keep on dancing at the
 Pink Pony Club

In a 2023 interview with Teen Vogue, Roan stated that the eponymous Pink Pony Club has become a real space through the crowd of her live shows, where drag queens are the openers and which are unapologetically queer, despite “whatever the fuck the lawmakers are doing.”:

The pink pony club not just as an idea, but as a real, tangible place she can create for people, if only for a night.  “You have to protect it,” she says. Queer joy, queer safety, queer love. “I have to protect it.”

Oh mama, I’m just having fun
 On the stage in my heels
 It’s where I belong down at the

The daughter understands her mother’s perspective but doesn’t listen because her perspective is different. She’s very happy to be doing what she does no matter what her mother thinks and she feels like she belongs.

God, what have you done
 You’re a pink pony girl
 And you dance at the club
This is most likely what the mother is saying to her daughter as she feels disapproval. She can’t believe that her daughter turned out this way.

annotations: Lana song

This refers to Lana Del Rey, an American singer-songwriter whose music explores traditional Americana aesthetics and unconventional romance. Her critically acclaimed music was hugely popular on social media platforms like Tumblr in the mid 2010’s.
She is known for popularising the ‘sad girl’ trope.

During a Q&A session on Reddit’s r/popheads subreddit, Roan revealed that the line referring to a “Lana song” is actually referring to two songs by Lana Del Rey: “Ride” and “Mariners Apartment Complex.”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nvb8wdBglpw

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1uFv9Ts7Sdw

Let’s make it cinematic
 Like that one sex scene that’s in Mulholland Drive

Chappell refers to a scene in Mullholland Drive, a  2001 surrealist film by David Lynch, in which two female characters, Betty; a bright-eyed wannabe actor and Rita; a femme fatale with amnesia, have sex: a moment of clarity and passion in an otherwise disorienting and confusing story for the characters.

Lynch has often been praised for his cinematography, and also recieved accolade for his depiction of Betty and Rita’s relationship in Mullholland Drive. Chappell wishes her encounter with her friend will be equally as ‘cinematic’.

Mean Girls, we watch it every night
 And we both have a crush on Regina George

Regina George, portrayed by Rachel McAdams in the 2004 comedy Mean Girls is a confident, fashion forward, often cruel queen bee and head of high school clique ‘The Plastics’.

https://meangirls.fandom.com/wiki/Regina_George

Interestingly, queer readings of the film often interpret Regina as a lesbian or queer woman as many of her actions within the film can be interpreted as stemming from internalised homophobia.

https://heycheyennehey.com/2021/06/02/definitive-proof-regina-george-is-queer/
Could go to hell but we’ll probably be fine

In certain religious groups, engaging in homosexual activity can be considered a sin. In typically conservative intepretations of Christianity where being gay is considered a sin, these ‘sinners’ are punished by being sent to hell after death.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homosexuality_and_religion

Reclaiming and joking about ‘being sent to hell’ is a common theme in modern queer expression, seen here in Chappell’s lyrics and in other queer artist’s work such as the music video for Lil Nas X’s Montero (Call Me By Your Name). https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6swmTBVI83k

Chappell makes reference to religious intolerance and a lack of concern as it’ll ‘probably be fine’ both to demonstrate the absurdity of homophobia in society but also to illustrate her feelings towards the girl she sings about, which are building in urgency to the point where she does not care about any potential consequences.

description.plain:
“My Kink Is Karma” is a song by the American singer-songwriter Chappell Roan. The song is about the concept of karma, which is the idea that our actions in this life will have consequences in the future. In the song, Roan explores the idea of how the universe will eventually bring justice to those who do wrong, and that the cycle of cause and effect will catch up with them.

The title “My Kink Is Karma” is a play on words; the phrase “my kink is…” is often used in pop culture to describe an unusual or unconventional sexual preference. However, in this song, Roan is using the phrase to express her belief that the concept of karma is what drives her actions and decisions in life, particularly with regard to her ex-lover.

Overall, the song is a thought-provoking exploration of the idea of karma and its place in our lives, with Roan’s haunting vocals and poignant lyrics adding depth and emotion to the message.

body.plain:
“My Kink Is Karma” is a song by the American singer-songwriter Chappell Roan. The song is about the concept of karma, which is the idea that our actions in this life will have consequences in the future. In the song, Roan explores the idea of how the universe will eventually bring justice to those who do wrong, and that the cycle of cause and effect will catch up with them.

The title “My Kink Is Karma” is a play on words; the phrase “my kink is…” is often used in pop culture to describe an unusual or unconventional sexual preference. However, in this song, Roan is using the phrase to express her belief that the concept of karma is what drives her actions and decisions in life, particularly with regard to her ex-lover.

annotations:
You ruining your life
 You losing your mind
 You dyeing your hair
 People say I’m jealous but my kink is watching
 You crashing your car
 You breaking your heart
 You thinking I care
 People say I’m jealous but my kink is karma

These lines suggest that the singer is observing someone, in this case, an ex-lover, who is self-destructive and making poor choices in their life.

The singer indicates people accuse her of being jealous of the person, but the truth is that her “kink” or fascination is watching them suffer the consequences of their actions. In this context, “kink” is being used figuratively to express a fascination or obsession with a particular topic or behavior.

The chorus of the song further emphasizes the concept of karma and its consequences. The singer implies that she is not concerned about the person’s behavior because she believes that the universe will eventually bring justice and the person will reap what they sow.

Overall, the lyrics suggest a sense of detachment and detachment towards the person’s situation, while also exploring the themes of cause and effect and the concept of karma.

annotations:
Ladies
 You know what I mean
 And you know what you need
 And so does he
 But does it happen? (No!)
 But does it happen? (No!)
 Well, what we really need is a femininomenon
 (A what?)
 A femininomenon

Chappell Roan for Teen Vogue, 2023:

“I love anthemic pop. I just go in to the studio every time like, how do we make the biggest, funnest song ever?…I saw a Queen video where they’re singing ‘Radio Ga Ga’ at [Wembley] stadium and the whole crowd was doing this thing. I was like, how do I make the crowd do that?”

 It’s a femininomenon (It’s a fem)
 Hit it like rom-pom-pom-pom (Hit it like)
 Get it hot like Papa John (Get it hot)
 Make a bitch go on and on (Make a bitch)
 It’s a femininomenon (It’s a fem)

This chorus was controversial with some fans upon the song’s first release, calling it “jarring,” according to Chappell Roan’s 2023 Teen Vogue Profile. However, as she performed it live throughout her time touring with Fletcher, the song’s vision was fully realized by fans:

When she released “Femininomenon,” about an online relationship gone sour, friends and fans told her it was “jarring.” (Kayleigh interjects herself: “Side note, I don’t know why people feel the need to tell me this every night. Someone’s like, I hated that song when you put it out. I’m like, fire.”) Experiencing “Femininomenon” live, however, is transcendent, iconic. She had the vision the whole time."

search_results.title: School  Nights
search_results.lyrics:
School  Nights Lyrics[Verse 1]
I'm feeling childish
When you draw tattoos on my forearm
Pop bubblegum too loud
We got them preachin' that we're hell-bound

[Pre-Chorus]
But I don't think we are unless you do

[Chorus]
I wanna be a kid with you
Talk slow on a school night
And you can disregard my virgin ears and say what you like
You wanna win me over now?
Impress me like a school fight
And I triple-dog dare ya
To pinky-promise that you'll never lie
Ooh ooh oh
[Verse 2]
We light firecrackers in the middle of the street
You hear them yellin' at us
But you, listen to me
As I pour my voice in your soul
You say "goddamn let's never get old," and
I agree

Talk slow on a school night
And you can disregard my virgin ears and say what you like

And I triple-dog dare ya

You're King Kong

You're so strong
But I wannna stay young
Yeah, I wanna stay young with you
Yeah, I wanna stay young
Yeah, I wanna stay young with you
Wanna stay young
I wanna stay young with you
Wanna stay young
I wanna stay young
You might also like[Chorus]

And you can disregard my virgin ears and say what you like

And I triple-dog dare ya

description.plain: Chappel Roan wrote School Nights at summer camp. She was feeling so strange because she was getting older but wanted to stay young, and there was nothing she could do about it. She wanted to be with someone who made her feel like a kid. She wanted to write about the feeling of having a crush on someone and staying up late thinking about them on a school night and being so excited to see them the next day. Chappel’s happy she captured that feeling when she because now she’s out of school, and there’s a different type of anticipation that she feels.

body.plain: Chappel Roan wrote School Nights at summer camp. She was feeling so strange because she was getting older but wanted to stay young, and there was nothing she could do about it. She wanted to be with someone who made her feel like a kid. She wanted to write about the feeling of having a crush on someone and staying up late thinking about them on a school night and being so excited to see them the next day. Chappel’s happy she captured that feeling when she because now she’s out of school, and there’s a different type of anticipation that she feels.

song.embed_content: Read “Bitter” by Chappell Roan on Genius
song.title: Bitter

annotations:
I love being bitter
 It makes me feel better
 Bitter feels better than tryna get better and I

In an interview with Atwood Magazine, Chappell Roan stated, “When I wrote this, I genuinely felt that being bitter felt better than trying to get better and failing. I was so bitter about my past relationship and how hurt I was, that it was affecting how I looked at others and myself. This song helped me realize that bitterness is like drinking poison and expecting it to kill someone else.”
